results.title: City port
results.creator_credit: Abacus Documentaries, David Powell and Roger Dunton
results.brief_description: Shows how the City of London, Lloyd’s, the Bank of England and other commercial institutions support the Port of London, and how the Port supplies goods to the city.

results.title: City out of time
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly and Colin Low
results.brief_description: A portrait of Venice that expores the rich legacy of art bequeathed to all. Two hundred years ago Canaletto caught its elusive beauty, and in this film details of his pictures rise before you - spired churches and turreted palaces soar into a blue Mediterranean sky. Narrated by William Shatner. (Award: Vancouver)

results.title: City of the sixties
results.creator_credit: Cinesound, Brisbane City Council and Stuart Glover
results.brief_description: Made for the Brisbane City Council showing the advances and achievements reached by capital of Queensland, Brisbane. Contains short clips of the Council’s activities such as roads and public transport, health, childcare etc as well as a celebration of cultural achievements of the city.

results.title: City of the angels
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Keith Adam and Geoffrey Barnes
results.brief_description: In the late 18th century, Rama I, first of the great Chakri kings, ordered his architects to build a new capital for Thailand - Bangkok. In Thai, Bangkok is called the “City of Angels”. Today one tenth of Thailand’s population lives in Bangkok, the most urbanised city in Thailand, which contains all the elements of Thai life seen in the extreme. Presenter Keith Adam, takes us on a tour of this city of contrast, a city of canals, superb temples and palaces alongside bustling markets, traffic jams, pollution and poverty.

results.title: City of many faces
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Lew Parry and David Bennett
results.brief_description: Mountain-fringed, poised on the Pacific, Vancouver is endowed with the natural beauty of flowers, parks and beaches. But even more in the forefront is summer skiing, yachting on the Strait, football at Empire Stadium, plays and concerts at the Queen Elizabeth Theater, and visits to the ever-fascinating zoo in Stanley Park.

results.title: City of gold
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Colin Low and Wolf Koenig
results.brief_description: A nostalgic recollection of the period when the Yukon gold fever was at its height. The commentary, written and spoken by Dawson-born Pierre Berton, begins with childhood recollections of the writer. This feeling of retrospect is further deepened by the introduction of many vintage photographs which give the film a documentary quality as it reviews the history of the gold rush. We see relics of the old Dawson as it was when all the gold of the rich river beds flowed through its stores, taverns and dance halls.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Colin Low and Wolf Koenig

results.title: City of Geelong
results.creator_credit: Shell Company of Australia, John Heyer and Bern Gandy
results.brief_description: One hundred years ago, Geelong was aboriginal country. Today, from a town which was built on wool and wheat, it has grown to be one of the biggest regional cities in Australia. Besides serving as the natural port for the produce from the rich hinterland farms, it has developed many secondary industries which make it the most industrialised city per head in Australia. Fine modern buildings, famous schools, and beautiful beaches show it as an attractive and happy city. Nestled around Corio Bay, it is prosperous and expanding.

results.title: City of dreams: the collaboration of Marion Mahon and Walter Burley Griffin
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Gaby Mason and Belinda Mason
results.brief_description: Walter Burley Griffin and Marion Mahony have long enjoyed accolades as one of the most important artistic collaborations of the 20th Century. In this documentary an overview of the collaboration of Walter Burley Griffin and wife and architectural partner Marion Mahony is addressed. The documentary connects the historical time-line of events in their lives to not only inform us about the architecture, but the political environment and the role that their personal dynamics had in contributing to their work. From early beginnings as the world’s first registered women architect and long-time designer for Frank Lloyd Wright, Marion Mahony is described as being Griffin’s intellectual sparring partner, muse and mentor. Documented is the incredible political corruption that Walter and Marion were confronted with and endured in Australia once being awarded the prize for their design of the new capital. Although they both decided to stay on in Australia after Canberra was completed and together produced almost 300 buildings around the country (including Sydney’s Castlecrag), it is evident that both lives suffered as a result of their ongoing battles with bureaucracy over the building of Canberra. What Marion and Walter have left is a legacy of strong vision and philosophical interest. Their dedication to their dream and aesthetic that sensitively addressed the environment and the balance of humans within this remains in their gardens and buildings.

results.title: City of chromatic dissolution
results.brief_description:
Arthur and Corinne Cantrill used footage of Melbourne’s cityscapes and buildings from the mid 1980s to create this evocative piece on movement, colour and the city. The various parts of inner city Melbourne were originally shot on black and white negative in three colour separation, then printed on Eastmancolor film. The results are static shots of the city, where the movement of people and vehicles have a quality that is colour saturated and ghostly. This is complemented with a sountrack both urban and discordant in tone.
This is one of a series of films made by the Cantrills that experiment with dramatic distortions of colour through three-colour separation processes. The original inspiration for this project (as the filmmakers report in the final edition of Cantrills Filmnotes) came back in the mid-1970s when Kodak stopped making the Cantrills’ preferred 16mm reversal colour film stocks.
